(decibels)   Octave Band 
(cycles per second) Residential Commercial     0-75 65 79    75-149 60 74   150-299 55 66   300-599 55 59   600-1,199 45 53 1,200-2,399 45 47 2,400-4,799 40 41 4,800 and over 40 39  
(Code 1979, § 6-7133) 
Secs. 8-94-8-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POLLUTION CONTROL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Powers of municipalities generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 48-3-20. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-121. - Title; definitions. 
(a)  The provisions embraced within this article shall constitute and be known and may be cited as the Pollution Control Ordinance. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air contaminant means dust, fumes, mist, smoke, other particulate matter, vapor, gas or any combination thereof. 
    Air pollution means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one or more air contaminants in such quantities and duration as is or tends to be injurious to human health or welfare, animal or plant life, or property, or interferes with the enjoyment of life or property. 
    Building official means the officer charged with the administration of the inspection division, and as defined in the Official Building Code of the City of Columbia, Part I, Building. 
    Engineer means a duly registered and licensed engineer. 
    Existing source means equipment, machines, devices, articles, contrivances or installations which are in being on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, except that any existing equipment, machine, device, article, contrivance or installation which is altered, replaced or rebuilt after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be reclassified as a new source. 
    Fuel-burning equipment means any furnace, boiler, apparatus or stack, and all appurtenances thereto, used in the process of burning fuel for the primary purpose of producing heat or power by indirect heat transfer. 
    Fugitive dust means solid airborne particulate matter emitted from any source other than a flue or stack. 
    Fumes means the solid particles generated by condensation from the gaseous state, generally after volatilization from melted substances and often accompanied by a chemical reaction such as oxidation. 
    Multiple-chamber incinerator means any article, machine, equipment, contrivance, structure or part of a structure used to dispose of combustible refuse by burning, consisting of three or more refractory line combustion furnaces in series, physically separated by refractory walls, interconnected by gas passage ports or ducts and employing adequate design parameters necessary for maximum combustion of the material to be burned. 
    New source means equipment, machines, devices, articles, contrivances or installations built or installed on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, and installations existing at such stated time which are later altered, repaired or rebuilt. Any equipment moved to another premises involving a change of address, or purchased and to be operated by a new owner, or by a new lessee when a new lessee desires to operate such equipment, after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, shall be considered a new source. 
    Opacity means a state which renders material partially or wholly impervious to rays of light and causes obstruction of an observer's view. 
    Open burning means the burning of any matter in such a manner that the products of combustion resulting from the burning are emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through an adequate stack, duct or chimney. 
    Particulate matter means any material, except water in uncombined form, that is or has been airborne and exists as a liquid or a solid at standard conditions. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, firm, association, trust, estate, public or private institution, group, agency, or political subdivision of this state, any other state or political subdivision or agency thereof, or any legal successor, representative, agent or agency of such individual or entity. 
    Ringelmann chart means the chart published and described in the U.S. Bureau of Mines Information Circular 8333, or any device equivalent to the Ringelmann Chart as may be designated by the building official. 
    Smoke means small gas-borne particles consisting essentially of carbonaceous materials in sufficient number to be observable. 
    Source means any property, real or personal, or person contributing to air pollution. 
    Stack and chimney mean any flue, conduit or duct arranged to conduct emissions. 
    Standard conditions means a dry gas temperature of 70 degrees Fahrenheit and a gas pressure of 14.7 pounds per square inch absolute. 
    Vehicle means a self-propelled mechanism, other than a railroad locomotive, such as a roller, derrick, crane, trencher, portable hoisting engine, steamboat, tug, automobile, truck and other apparatus which is not ordinarily permanently installed in one location but is used at various places over a wide location. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7001) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-122. - Purpose of article. 
    The provisions of this article are declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health and general welfare through the proper control of pollutants. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7002) 
Sec. 8-123. - Scope of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to the installation, alteration, repair, maintenance and use of all materials and equipment and its appurtenances which cause pollutants to be discharged into the atmosphere. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7003) 
Sec. 8-124. - Determination of requirements for equipment not specifically covered. 
    Any requirements necessary for effectuating the purpose of this article and for the installation, alteration or repair of equipment not specifically covered by this article shall be determined by the pollution control officer, with the advice and approval of the pollution control advisory board, subject to appeal to the board of appeals. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7004) 
Sec. 8-125. - Applicability of article to existing installations. 
    Upon notice of violation of any of the general regulations of this article, existing equipment and appurtenances shall be altered or modified so as to eliminate such violation. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7005) 
Sec. 8-126. - Maintenance of installations. 
    All installations covered by this article, both existing and new, and all parts thereof, shall be maintained in a satisfactory condition so as not to violate any of the terms of this article. The owner or his designated agent shall be responsible for the maintenance of equipment and appurtenances. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7006) 
Sec. 8-127. - Inspections. 
(a)  Required. All new installations and such portions of existing installations as may be affected by new work or changes shall be inspected to ensure compliance with the requirements of this article and to ensure that the installation and construction are in accordance with approved plans. 
(b)  Final inspection of newly installed equipment. A final inspection and approval shall be requested and made prior to the placing in operation of any fuel-burning equipment installed under a properly issued permit. 
(c)  Notification of building official when work is ready for inspection. It shall be the duty of the installer to notify the building official when he is ready for inspection. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-7007-6-7009) 
Sec. 8-128. - Air pollution prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or cause air pollution, as defined in this article. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7011) 
Sec. 8-129. - Compliance with article. 
    All sources of pollution shall comply with this article upon commencing operation. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7012) 
Sec. 8-130. - Dilution or concealment of emissions. 
    No person shall cause or permit the installation or use of any device or any means which, without resulting in reduction in the total amount of air contaminant emitted, conceals or dilutes an emission of air contaminant which would otherwise violate the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7013) 
Sec. 8-131. - Open burning. 
(a)  All open burning is prohibited without special permit issued by the pollution control officer with concurrence of the fire department in exceptional cases, except as follows: 
(1)  Open fires may be set in performance of an official duty of any public officer if the fire is necessary for the prevention of a hazard which cannot be abated by other means, for the instruction of public firefighters under the supervision of the fire chief, or for the protection of public health. 
(2)  Fires may be used for the cooking of food, provided no smoke violation or other nuisance is created. 
(3)  Salamanders or other devices may be used for heating by construction or other workers, provided no smoke violation or other nuisance is created. 
(4)  Fires may be set in the course of agricultural operations in growing crops or raising fowl or animals, provided no nuisance is created. 
(5)  Open fires may be set for recreational purposes, such as campfires, provided no smoke violation or nuisance is created. 
(b)  Fires started in violation of this article shall be promptly extinguished by the person responsible for the fire upon proper notice by the pollution control officer or his agent. During the existence of a pollution alert, as may be declared by designated authorities, all exceptions are void and no open fires shall be kindled. Where possible, all open burning in progress during an alert will be extinguished immediately by responsible persons when properly notified. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7014) 
Secs. 8-132-8-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 8-151. - Pollution control division. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established in and as a part of the department of community development, a pollution control division, which shall be under the supervision of the building official and in charge of the pollution control officer. 
(b)  Appointment of inspectors and other employees. The building official, with the approval of the city manager, may appoint such inspectors, assistants or other employees as shall be authorized from time to time. No person shall be appointed as a pollution control officer until he has been thoroughly examined and his qualifications are firmly established to act as such. 
(c)  Conflicts of interest. No officer or employee connected with the department, except one whose only connection is as a member of the board established by this article, shall be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material or appliances for equipment or appurtenances or in making of plans or specifications therefor, unless he is the owner of such building. No such officer or employee shall engage in any work which is inconsistent with his duties or the interest of the department. 
(d)  Records. The pollution control officer shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of the business of the pollution control division. The records of the division shall be open to public inspection at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-7021-6-7024) 
Sec. 8-152. - Powers and duties of pollution control officer. 
(a)  Enforcement of article; right of entry. The pollution control officer shall enforce the provisions of this article, and he or his duly authorized representative may enter any building, structure or premises in the city to perform any duty imposed upon him by this article. 
(b)  Stop work orders. Upon notice from the pollution control officer that work on any type of installation is being done contrary to the provisions of this article, or in a manner so as to violate any permit issued, such work shall be immediately stopped. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of such property or his agent or to the person doing the work and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where any emergency exists, oral notice given by the pollution control officer shall be sufficient. 
(c)  Sealing of equipment. Where any individual fails to comply within a reasonable time with any order issued by the pollution control officer, the pollution control officer shall then seal the equipment. The seal shall not be broken on this equipment until such time as corrections have been made; provided, however, that the individual may appeal the decision to the appeals board as established in this division and a properly made appeal shall give the pollution control officer the authority to remove the seal, unless the pollution control officer's opinion is that an emergency exists. 
(d)  Revocation of permits. The pollution control officer may revoke a permit and approval issued under the provisions of this article in case there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to material fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based. In all such cases no permit fees shall be refunded. 
(e)  Annual report. The pollution control officer shall annually submit a report to the building official covering the work of the pollution control division during the preceding year. He shall incorporate in the report a summary of decisions and examinations of the board of appeals and the rules and regulations as established by the pollution control advisory board. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-7031-6-7035) 
Sec. 8-153. - Pollution control appeals board. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established a pollution control appeals board. 
(b)  Membership; compensation of members. The pollution control appeals board established by this section shall consist of five members, and they shall serve without compensation. 
(c)  Appointment and qualifications of members. The members of the appeals board shall be appointed by the city council, and they shall have the following qualifications. None of the members shall be a member of the pollution control advisory board. 
(1)  One of the members shall be an attorney at law. 
(2)  One member shall be a professional engineer. 
(3)  One member shall be a representative of the industrial interests of the city. 
(4)  Two members shall be representatives of the citizens of the city and shall not in any way be connected with the fields of endeavor of the appointees listed in subsections (1) through (3) of this subsection. 
(d)  Term of members. Of the members first appointed, one shall be appointed for a term of one year, one shall be appointed for a term of two years, one shall be appointed for a term of three years, one shall be appointed for a term of four years, and one shall be appointed for a term of five years. Thereafter, they shall be appointed for a term of five years. 
(e)  Termination of appointments. Appointments to the appeals board as established by this section shall be terminated by the city council. 
(f)  Quorum. Three members of the board shall constitute a quorum. In upholding an appeal, the affirmative vote of the majority present, but not less than three affirmative votes, shall be required. 
(g)  Conflicts of interest. No member of the appeals board shall act in a case in which he has a personal interest. 
(h)  Records. The pollution control officer shall act as secretary to the appeals board and shall make a detailed report of all its proceedings, which shall set forth the reasons for its decisions, the vote of each member participating therein, the absence of any member and any failure of any member to vote. 
(i)  Rules of procedure; meetings. The board shall establish rules for its own procedure, not inconsistent with the provisions of this article. The appeals board shall meet at regular intervals to be determined by the chairman. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-7061-6-7069) 
Sec. 8-154. - Appeal procedure; decisions on appeals. 
(a)  Right of appeal. Whenever the pollution control officer shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of a proposed installation or materials to be used in the installation, or when it is claimed that the provisions of this article do not apply or that any equally good or more desirable form of installation can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of this article or any of the regulations under this article have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the owner of the building or structure or his duly authorized agent may appeal from the decision of the pollution control officer to the pollution control appeals board. 
(b)  Time limit for filing appeal. 
(1)  Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within 30 days after a decision is rendered by the pollution control officer. 
(2)  In case of an installation which in the opinion of the pollution control officer constitutes an immediate hazard, the pollution control officer may, on his order, limit the time for such an appeal to a shorter period. 
(c)  Powers of appeals board. 
(1)  The pollution control appeals board, when appealed to and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of this article in any particular case, when in its opinion the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of this article and the public interest, or when in its opinion the interpretation of the pollution control officer should be modified or reversed. 
(2)  A decision of the appeals board to vary the application of any provision of this article or to modify an order of the pollution control officer shall specify in what manner such a variation or modification has been made, the conditions upon which it is made, and the reasons therefor. 
(d)  Decisions by appeals board. 
(1)  Every decision of the pollution control appeals board shall be final, subject, however, to such remedy as an aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. It shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote upon the decision. Every decision shall be promptly filed in the office of the building official and shall be open to public inspection. Certified copies should be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant and a copy shall be publicly posted in the office of the building official for two weeks after filing. 
(2)  The appeals board shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. 
(3)  If a decision of the appeals board reverses or modifies a refusal order or disallowance of the pollution control officer or varies application of any phrase of this article, the pollution control officer shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-7081-6-7084) 
Secs. 8-155-8-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT 

Sec. 8-171. - Required. 
(a)  Any owner, authorized agent or contractor who desires to install, construct, enlarge, alter or repair any apparatus or equipment, the installation of which is regulated by this article or by the rules and regulations provided for in this article, or to cause any such work to be done, shall first make application to the building official and obtain the required permit therefor. 
(b)  Ordinary minor repairs may be made without the approval of the pollution control officer, without a permit, provided that such repairs shall not violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7091) 
Sec. 8-172. - Filing of application. 
    An application for permit as required by the provisions of this division shall be filed with the building official prior to the starting of any construction or installation work. Such application shall be made in duplicate. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7092) 
Sec. 8-173. - Coordination of applications. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official to coordinate all applications required by this article and other ordinances. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7093) 
Sec. 8-174. - Submission of plans and specifications. 
    When, in the opinion of the pollution control officer, plans and specifications are required in order to determine that a proposed installation, alteration or repair of equipment and its appurtenances will comply with the terms of this article and the rules and regulations provided for in this article, such plans and specifications shall be submitted with the application for a permit; provided, however, that when fuel-burning equipment to be installed is in excess of a capacity of 400,000 Btu, plans and specifications shall be submitted with the application for a permit. The plans shall give all installation and construction details for the proposed work. The plans shall be submitted in duplicate, one copy of which shall be retained in the permanent files of the city, and the second copy of which shall be for the use of the pollution control officer. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7094) 
Sec. 8-175. - Examination of application and plans. 
    The building official shall examine or cause to be examined each application for a permit under this division and the drawings and specifications which may be filed therewith, and shall ascertain by such examination whether the proposed installation indicated and described is in accordance with this article and all other pertinent laws or ordinances. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7095) 
Sec. 8-176. - Fee. 
    Each application for a permit under this division shall be accompanied by the permit fee as established by the official building code of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7096) 
Sec. 8-177. - Action on application. 
(a)  If the building official is satisfied that the work described in an application for a permit under this division, and the drawings and specifications which may be filed therewith, conform to the requirements of this article and other pertinent laws and ordinances, he shall issue a permit therefor to the applicant. 
(b)  If the application for the permit and the drawings and specifications which may be filed therewith describe work which does not conform to the requirements of this article or other pertinent laws or ordinances, the building official shall not issue a permit but shall return the drawings to the applicant with his refusal to issue such a permit. Such refusal shall, when requested, be in writing and shall contain the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7097) 
Sec. 8-178. - Conditions; expiration. 
    The building official shall act upon an application for a permit under this division with plans, as filed or as amended, without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. The permit issued shall be construed to be permission to proceed with the work and shall not be construed as authority to violate, cancel, alter or set aside the provisions of this article or any other applicable code, nor shall issuance of a permit prevent the building official from thereafter requiring correction of errors in plans or in construction or of violations of this article. Any permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by it shall have been commenced within six months after its issuance or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of one year after the time the work is commenced; provided that, for cause, one or more extensions of time for periods not exceeding 90 days each may be allowed in writing by the building official. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7098) 
Secs. 8-179-8-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VISIBLE EMISSION STANDARDS 

Sec. 8-201. - Emission restrictions for existing sources. 
    No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit to be discharged into the atmosphere from any single source of emission existing prior to March 1, 1972, any air contaminant of a shade or density equal to that designated as no. 2 on the Ringelmann chart or 40 percent opacity. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7111) 
Sec. 8-202. - Emission restrictions for new sources. 
(a)  No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit to be discharged into the atmosphere from any single source of emission created after March 1, 1972, any air contaminants of a shade or density equal to that designated as no. 1 on the Ringelmann chart or 20 percent opacity. 
(b)  A person may discharge into the atmosphere from any single fuel-burning or combustion source for a period not to exceed more than four minutes in any 60 minutes air contaminants of a shade or density not darker than no. 3 on the Ringelmann chart or 60 percent opacity. 
(c)  The exception described in subsection (b) of this section shall not be permitted in excess of three times in any 24-hour period. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7112) 
Sec. 8-203. - Control of fugitive dust; handling and disposal of asbestos. 
(a)  Dust control generally. No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit any materials to be handled, transported or stored, or a building, its appurtenances or a road to be used, constructed, altered, repaired or demolished, without taking reasonable precautions to prevent particulate matter from becoming airborne. Such reasonable precautions shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Use, where possible, of water or chemicals for control of dust in the demolition of existing buildings or structures, construction operations, the grading of roads or the clearing of land. 
(2)  Application of asphalt, oil, water or suitable chemicals on dirt roads, materials stockpiles and other surfaces which can create airborne dusts. 
(3)  Installation and use of hoods, fans and fabric filters to enclose and vent the handling of dusty materials. Adequate containment methods shall be employed during sandblasting or other similar operations. 
(4)  Covering, at all times when in motion, open-bodied trucks transporting materials likely to become airborne. 
(5)  Conduct of agricultural practices, such as tilling of land, application of fertilizers, etc., in such manner as to not create a nuisance to others residing in the area. 
(b)  Unlawful use of sealed equipment. No person shall violate the seal on any equipment that has been sealed at the direction of the pollution control officer unless authorized by him in writing to do so. 
(c)  National emission standards for asbestos. 
(1)  When any owner or operator of a demolition or renovation operation intends to demolish any institutional, commercial or industrial building (including apartment buildings having more than four dwelling units), structure, facility, installation or portion thereof which contains any pipe, duct, boiler, tank, reactor, turbine, furnace or structural member that is insulated or fireproofed with friable asbestos material, or intends to renovate any institutional, commercial or industrial building, structure, facility, installation or portion thereof where more than 80 meters (about 260 feet) of pipe insulated or fireproofed with friable asbestos material are to be stripped or removed, or more than 15 square meters (about 160 square feet) of friable asbestos material used to insulate or fireproof any duct or boiler, tank, reactor, turbine, furnace or structural member are to be stripped or removed, such asbestos material shall be adequately wetted prior to and during such demolition, renovation or related handling operations. 
(2)  The disposal of all asbestos material generated by demolition shall be accomplished by depositing it in a disposal site approved by federal regulations and those of the state department of health and environmental control. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7113) 
Sec. 8-204. - Smoke indicators or observation devices. 
    All newly constructed or reconstructed solid or liquid fuel-burning plants having more than 300 square feet of boiler surface (30 hp) or its equivalent shall be equipped with smoke indicators, mirrors or similar devices, approved by the pollution control officer, to enable the fireman to observe the top of his stack from the boiler room at all times, unless the top of the stack is readily visible to the fireman from the boiler room without the use of such devices. In plants where a fireman is not in constant attendance in the boiler room, the smoke indicator shall be of a type which will sound an alarm, or flash a signal, to attract the attention of the fireman. Any existing plant which emits unlawful visible emissions may be required to install such indicating devices. 
(Code 1979, § 6-7114) 
Sec. 8-205. - Process weight emission limitations. 
(a)  No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit the emission of particulate matter in any one hour from any source in excess of the amount shown in table II for the process weight rate allocated to such source or in excess of 0.03 grain per standard cubic foot of exhaust gas.
