(Code 1979, § 6-4103) 
Sec. 17-468. - Conflicting provisions; amendments. 
(a)  Conflicting provisions. Whenever the provisions of this article impose more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other ordinance, the regulations contained in this article shall prevail. Whenever the provisions of any other ordinance require more restrictive standards than are required in this article, the requirements of those regulations shall prevail. 
(b)  Amendments. This article may be amended after notice and public hearing in the same manner as prescribed by law for its original adoption. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4104) 
Secs. 17-469-17-490. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLAT APPROVAL 

Sec. 17-491. - Generally. 
(a)  Major subdivisions. The procedure for review and approval of a major subdivision plat consists of three separate steps. These are: 
(1)  Review of the sketch plan by the staff of the planning commission; 
(2)  Review and approval of the preliminary plat (construction drawings) by the planning commission and city engineer; and 
(3)  Review and approval of the final plat by the planning commission and as-built drawing by the city engineer. 
(b)  Minor subdivisions. Minor subdivisions which do not involve the platting, construction or opening of new streets, water or sewer facilities, storm drainage systems, or improvements to existing streets may be accepted for review by the planning commission in the form of a final plat. Sketch plans and preliminary plats are not required in such cases. However, the city engineer may require a service connection plan and a grading plan. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4011) 
Sec. 17-492. - Procedures and plan requirements. 
    The following procedures shall be followed in the submission, review and action upon all subdivision plats: 
(1)  Sketch plan review. 
a.  The subdivider or his representative shall present seven copies of a sketch plan to the staff of the planning commission, prepared in accordance with this article, for review and approval. Suggested street names and any phasing of the proposed subdivision shall be identified. 
b.  The staff shall review the sketch plan for conformity with applicable zoning, development plans for the area, floodplain information and other pertinent community plans and approve or disapprove the sketch plan within 15 working days. Failure of the staff of the planning commission to act within 15 days after submission of the sketch plan shall be deemed to constitute sketch plan approval; provided, however, that the subdivider may waive this requirement and consent in writing to the extension of that period. 
c.  If the sketch plan is disapproved by the staff or the staff requires changes with which the subdivider does not concur, the subdivider may submit the sketch plan to the planning commission at its next regular meeting. Notice of the time and place of that meeting shall be sent by registered certified mail to the address specified on the plat not less than five days before the meeting. The planning commission shall review and approve, disapprove, or approve with modifications the sketch plan at the meeting at which it is presented. Pertinent comments and recommendations shall be noted on the minutes of the planning commission meeting. 
(2)  Sketch plan requirements. Sketch plans shall be prepared in accordance with the following requirements: 
a.  The sketch plan shall be drawn at a scale of not smaller than 100 feet to one inch. 
b.  The sketch plan shall include a vicinity map at a scale of one inch to 1,000 feet showing the relationship of the proposed subdivision to surrounding development. 
c.  The sketch plan shall show: 
1.  Total acreage in the tract to be subdivided, tentative phasing plan and total acreage per phase, if applicable; 
2.  Street, driveway, and lot arrangements, each fully dimensioned; 
3.  Rights-of-way and ingress/egress easements, each fully dimensioned; 
4.  Lot area and number of lots or dwelling units in multifamily dwellings; 
5.  Existing and proposed uses of land throughout the subdivision; 
6.  Existing uses of land surrounding the subdivision, including existing street right-of-way widths abutting the subdivision and/or locations of intersections within 200 feet of the property; 
7.  Topography by contours at vertical intervals of not more than five feet, depicted in terms of mean sea level datum; 
8.  Proposed name of the subdivision, proposed street names, and name and address of the person to whom notice of hearing shall be sent; and 
9.  Tax map reference and existing zoning. 
(3)  Preliminary plat (construction drawings). The subdivider or his representative shall submit seven copies of a preliminary plat (construction drawings) to the staff of the planning commission. These construction drawings must contain the following: 
a.  Plans must be drawn to a scale of not less than one inch to 100 feet on sheets 24 inches by 36 inches, be dated, and carry the seal and signature of a registered professional engineer licensed to practice in the state. Where necessary, a 24-inch by 36-inch master plan sheet, drawn to appropriate scale, shall be included showing the relationship and sheet numbers of the various portions or phases of the subdivision. 
b.  The plans must show the proposed name of the subdivision, owner and/or subdivider, graphic scale, north point and date. The north point shall be identified as magnetic, true or grid north. 
c.  There shall be included a vicinity map at a scale of one inch equals 1,000 feet showing streets, roads and the relationship of the subdivision to the surrounding area. 
d.  The plan shall show the acreage to be subdivided, the phasing of the subdivision and number of acres in each phase, and the boundaries of the tract with all bearings and distances indicated. The boundary survey shall be to such a degree of accuracy that the error of closure shall comply with the standards set forth by the state board of engineering examiners. 
(4)  Existing conditions. The following existing conditions shall be shown on the preliminary plat: 
a.  Topography, in terms of mean sea level, by contours at vertical intervals of not more than five feet; 
b.  Deed record names of adjoining property owners or subdivisions; 
c.  In case of resubdivision, a copy of the existing plat with the proposed resubdivision superimposed thereon; 
d.  Location of streams, lakes, swamps and land subject to flood based on 100-year flood frequency. The boundaries of the floodplain and floodway for the 100-year flood shall be shown; 
e.  Location of existing adjoining property lines and buildings on the property to be subdivided; 
f.  Location and right-of-way of streets, intersections within 200 feet of the property, roads, railroads and utility lines either on or adjacent to the property to be subdivided. The plat shall specify whether utility lines are in easements or rights-of-way and show the location of poles or towers, width of right-of-way and name of the utility; 
g.  Size and location of existing sewers, water mains, drains, culverts or other underground facilities within the street or within the right-of-way of streets or roads adjoining or within the tract. Grades, invert and rim elevations of existing sewers shall be shown. If relocation of existing sewers is proposed, a complete plan and profile of existing conditions, as well as a plan and profile of proposed conditions, must be shown; 
h.  The acreage of each drainage area affecting the proposed subdivision; 
i.  Location of city limit lines and county lines, if applicable; and 
j.  Tax map reference and existing zoning. 
All elevations shall be expressed in mean sea level datum and this fact so stated on the drawings. 
(5)  Proposed conditions. The following proposed conditions shall be shown on the preliminary plat: 
a.  Layout of streets, roads and alleys, with widths; 
b.  Construction plans for streets showing natural and finished grades and cross sections. Where a proposed street is an extension of an existing street, the profile shall be extended to include 300 feet of the existing roadways; the cross section of the existing street also shall be shown; 
c.  Layout of all lots, scaled dimensions on lots, lot and block numbers, utility easements with width and use, and street names as approved on the sketch plan; 
d.  Construction plan and profile for sanitary sewers (if applicable), with grade, pipe size and material, location of manholes and points of discharge; 
e.  Construction plans for the storm drainage system, with grade, pipe size and material, and location of outlets. Storm drains shall be designed in accordance with criteria outlined in the city storm drainage ordinance (chapter 21, article II). Storm drainage plans shall show sufficient off-site information and include the method and computations where indicated, and a statement by a registered engineer or architect that storm drainage designs meet city ordinances must be provided; 
f.  Construction plans for the water supply system, with hydraulic calculation, pipe sizes, material and location of hydrants and valves; 
g.  Total number of lots, total acreage, acreage per phase, and total length of new streets; and 
h.  Proposed major contour changes in areas where substantial cut or fill is to be done. 
All proposed conditions shall be superimposed on a topographic map of existing conditions. 
(6)  Preliminary plat approval. Upon determination by the planning staff that the layout shown on the preliminary plat is in conformity with the approved sketch plan, the staff shall submit copies of these plans to the city engineer for review and approval. Upon receipt of reports from the city engineer, but in no case more than 30 days after submission of the preliminary plat (construction drawings), the staff shall schedule the review of these plans at the next regularly scheduled planning commission meeting. The planning commission may approve the plans subject to changes required by the reviewing agencies. The staff shall notify the subdivider or his representative and the reviewing agencies of that action. The planning commission approval of the preliminary plat or the approval of the preliminary plat subject to changes required by the reviewing agencies constitutes authority to the subdivider to construct site improvements in accordance with the approved preliminary plat. The start of actual construction must be scheduled with the city engineer. Preliminary plat approval shall be valid only for two years. If required improvements are not constructed within two years after preliminary plat approval, the plat must be resubmitted as a new application for approval subject to the subdivision regulations as amended to that date. 
(7)  Final plat approval. 
a.  After completion of the physical development of all or any approved phase of the area shown on the approved preliminary plat (construction drawings), the subdivider or his representative shall submit five copies of the final plat and one set of the as-built drawings in the form of a mylar to the staff of the planning commission. The final plat shall conform substantially to the approved preliminary plat and should be marked "final plat" on the title block. The as-built drawings shall conform substantially to the approved construction plans and shall be marked "as-built" in the title block. The final plat and as-built drawings shall be drawn to a scale not smaller than one inch equals 100 feet on 24-inch by 36-inch sheets and shall include the following information: 
1.  Name of subdivision, and name and address of the fee simple title holder conveying the improvements to the city. 
2.  Graphic scale, north point and date. The north point shall be identified as magnetic, true or grid north. 
3.  Vicinity map, at a scale of one inch equals 1,000 feet, showing the relationship of the subdivision to the surrounding area. 
4.  Street names, lot numbers and block numbers. 
5.  Sufficient data to determine readily and reproduce on the ground the location, bearing and length of every road right-of-way line, subdivision boundary line, lot line and block line, whether curved or straight. 
6.  All dimensions to the nearest one-tenth of a foot, and angles to the nearest minute. 
7.  Location and descriptions of monuments. 
8.  All rights-of-way, easements and areas to be dedicated to public use, with the purpose of each stated. 
9.  Certificates as follows: The following signed certificates shall appear on the final as-built drawings and final plat respectively: 
I hereby certify that the streets, storm drainage system, sanitary sewer system and water system in ___________ subdivision as shown on the plat dated ________, prepared by ___________, have been installed in accordance with the preliminary plat (construction drawings) approved ________. 
      (date)       ,      _____
Registered Engineer, State of South Carolina  
I hereby certify that the plan shown and described herein is a true and correct survey to the accuracy required by the City of Columbia Subdivision Regulations and the monuments shown have been placed to the specifications set forth in those regulations. 
      (date)       ,      Registration Number  _____ _____
Registered Land Surveyor  
10.  Sufficient data to determine and reproduce on the ground the location of all valves, fire hydrants, individual service lines and other appurtenances on water systems. Similar data for sanitary sewer lines, manholes, wyes, etc., shall be shown. Where utility lines run through easements or rights-of-way, their location in relation to easement lines must be shown. Location data shall be referenced to stable physical features such as curb corners, building corners, property corners, etc. Construction station numbers will not be used as references. 
11.  Tax map reference and zoning. 
b.  Upon determination by the planning staff that the layout shown on the final plat is in conformity with the approved preliminary plat, the staff shall submit one copy of the final plat and the as-built drawings to the city engineer for review and approval. If the city engineer does not act within 30 days, the planning commission will be furnished an interim report. After approval of the site improvements by the city engineer and completion of the proper dedications, or the acceptance of a surety bond in an amount covering the value of the uncompleted site improvements, the planning staff will schedule the final plat for review for the next regular planning commission meeting. Upon the approval of a final plat by the planning commission, the planning staff shall stamp two of the prints with the appropriate certificate of the planning commission and return them to the subdivider. This print shall become the instrument to be recorded in the office of the register of mesne conveyances. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4012; Ord. No. 2005-038, 5-8-05) 
Secs. 17-493-17-510. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MINIMUM DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 17-511. - Variances. 
    When, due to the peculiar shape or topography of a tract of land or other unusual condition, it is impractical for a developer to comply with the literal interpretation of the design requirements of this article, the planning commission shall be authorized, after considering recommendations from the city engineer, the fire department, the police department, and the public works department, to vary those requirements, provided the intent and purpose of this article are not violated. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4035; Ord. No. 2005-039, 5-18-05) 
Sec. 17-512. - Streets. 
    All streets which shall hereafter be established in connection with the development of a subdivision shall comply with the following design standards and city specifications for roadway design: 
(1)  Extension of existing streets. The arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall provide for the alignment and continuation or extension of existing streets in adjoining areas in the same or greater width than the minimum required by this article. 
(2)  Culs-de-sac. Culs-de-sac shall terminate in a circular turnaround having a minimum right-of-way of at least 100 feet in diameter and a paved turnaround with a minimum outside diameter of 80 feet, or other approved type of turnaround, including T's, Y's or landscaped islands. 
(3)  Temporary dead-end streets. Temporary dead-end streets which extend for a greater distance than the depth of one abutting lot shall be provided with a temporary turnaround having a roadway surface diameter of 80 feet, or other approved type of turnaround. 
(4)  Half streets. Half streets of less than two lanes are prohibited. Whenever a street is planned adjacent to the proposed subdivision tract boundary, the entire street right-of-way shall be platted within the proposed subdivision. 
(5)  Intersections. The centerline of no more than two streets shall intersect at any one point. Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as feasible at right angles, and no street shall intersect any other street at an angle of less than 60 degrees. The angle of intersection shall be measured at the intersection of street centerlines. Where curved streets intersect, the minor street shall have a minimum tangent of 100 feet at the intersection. 
(6)  Reverse curves. Where practical, a tangent of at least 150 feet on collector streets shall be provided between reverse curves. On major arterials, tangent distances shall be determined by use of standards of the state department of highways and public transportation. 
(7)  Street names. Streets or roads that are extensions of, or obviously in alignment with, existing named streets shall bear that name. The names of new streets and roads shall be subject to the approval of the planning commission and shall not duplicate or be similar in sound to existing names, irrespective of the use of the suffix "street," "avenue," "circle," "way," "boulevard," "drive," "place" or "court" or the like, unless, for orientation purposes, suffix streets are connected. 
(8)  Street access to unsubdivided property. Where it is deemed necessary to the development of a logical street pattern and transportation network, streets and rights-of-way shall be extended to the boundary of adjoining property. Incompatible characteristics of adjoining property shall be given due consideration in making a determination of what shall constitute a logical street pattern. Reserve strips adjoining street rights-of-way for the purpose of preventing access to adjacent property shall not be permitted. 
(9)  Intersection spacing. Street intersections shall have a centerline offset of not less than 200 feet, except that for street intersections on minor or local residential streets, the street intersection spacing shall be 125 feet. 
(10)  Additional right-of-way. Subdivisions which include or abut an existing platted street or road that does not conform to the minimum right-of-way requirements of this article shall dedicate additional width along one or both sides of that street or road so that the minimum right-of-way required by this article is established. Due consideration for proper street alignment shall be given to location of additional right-of-way required. Subdivisions abutting only one side of such a street or road shall dedicate a minimum of one-half, measured from the centerline of the existing right-of-way, of the right-of-way required by this article. 
(11)  Right-of-way and pavement width. Minimum rights-of-way and pavement widths shall be as follows: 
Street Classification Minimum 
Right-of-Way 
(feet) Minimum 
Pavement Width* 
(feet) Minor residential  50 28** Local residential  50 27*  Collector  60 36** Industrial or commercial service  80 36*  Arterial 100 52**  
*Pavement width is measured from low point to low point of curb. Minimum pavement widths and right-of-way may be reduced by the planning commission in individual cases upon written approval of the city engineer. 
**Measured from face to face of curb. 
(12)  Street grades, horizontal curves and vertical curves. Street grades, horizontal curves and vertical curves shall be in accordance with the provisions of Part 5, Specifications for Roadway Design, City of Columbia Regulations. 
(13)  Split level streets. Streets which are constructed so as to have two trafficways, each at a different level within the same right-of-way, shall provide a paved traffic surface of at least 20 feet on each level and a slope between the two trafficways of six to one or flatter. 
(14)  Alleys. Alleys shall not be provided except where the subdivider produces evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys. Where alleys are permitted, they shall be graded and surfaced to specifications approved by the city engineer and deeded to the city. 
(15)  Access to parks, schools, etc. Streets shall be designed or walkways dedicated to ensure convenient access to adjoining parks, playgrounds, schools and other places of public assembly. Dedicated walkways shall not be less than 15 feet in width. 
(16)  Relation to railroad rights-of-way. When a subdivision adjoins railroad right-of-way, the subdivider may be required to arrange the street pattern to provide for future grade separation of street and railroad crossings. 
(17)  Arterial streets shown on major thoroughfare plan. Whenever a tract of land to be subdivided includes any part of a street shown on the major thoroughfare plan approved by the planning commission and adopted by the council, a right-of-way for the arterial street shall be platted in the location and to the width specified in the thoroughfare plan. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4031) 
Sec. 17-513. - Blocks. 
(a)  Nonresidential blocks. Blocks for other than residential use shall be of such length and width as may be suitable for their prospective use, including adequate provision for off-street parking and service. 
(b)  Residential block length. In order that there may be convenient access between various parts of a subdivision, and in order to help prevent traffic congestion and undue inconvenience, the length of blocks hereafter established shall not exceed 1,800 feet or be less than 600 feet. 
(c)  Residential block width. The width of any residential block shall be sufficient to permit two tiers of lots. 
(d)  Cul-de-sac length. Culs-de-sac shall not exceed 1,000 feet. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4032) 
Sec. 17-514. - Lots. 
    All lots which shall hereafter be established in connection with the development of a subdivision shall comply with the following design standards: 
(1)  Authority of health department. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as preventing the health department, after study of the conditions existing in a proposed subdivision, from requiring that all or any portion of the area of that subdivision shall not be built upon or that the minimum lot sizes set forth in this article are inadequate and must be increased to ensure the protection of the public health. 
(2)  Lot lines and city limit or county lines. Lots should, insofar as practicable, not be divided by city limit or county boundary lines. 
(3)  Corner lots. Corner lots shall be of sufficient size so that a structure could be constructed and still maintain minimum yard requirements specified in the city zoning ordinance (article III of this chapter). 
(4)  Double frontage. Double frontage lots (i.e., lots having street frontage both in front and rear) shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from railroad or major street rights-of-way or from nonresidential uses. 
(5)  Lot lines. Insofar as practical, side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines and radial to curved street lines. 
(6)  Minimum lot dimensions and area. Minimum lot dimensions and area are governed by the city zoning ordinance (article III of this chapter) or applicable health regulations. 
(7)  Street access. Every lot hereafter established shall front or abut on a street which conforms to the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4033) 
Sec. 17-515. - Easements. 
    Easements shall be required in subdivisions for the following purposes: 
(1)  Utility easements. When it is found to be necessary and desirable to locate public utility lines in other than street rights-of-way, easements shall be shown on the plat for those purposes. All aboveground utilities shall be provided along rear property lines except where site conditions make this impractical. The easement shall be not less than 12 feet in width on rear property lines and ten feet on the side lines, and where feasible shall be centered on rear or side lot lines. City-owned utilities shall be installed in easements dedicated exclusively to the city. 
(2)  Watercourse and drainage easements. Where a proposed subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway or stream, appropriate provisions shall be made to accommodate stormwater and drainage through and from the proposed subdivision. The easement shall conform substantially with the lines of the watercourse and be of sufficient width or construction, or both, as to comply with the city storm drainage ordinance (Chapter 21, article II); provided, however, that public easements shall not be less than 12 feet in width. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4034) 
Secs. 17-516-17-530. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 17-531. - Required; installation. 
    A well-designed subdivision means little to a prospective lot buyer until he can see actual physical transformation of raw land into lots with all necessary improvements provided. Likewise, a well-designed subdivision is not an asset to the community until the necessary improvements shall have been installed. In order that prospective lot purchasers may get usable products and new subdivisions may be an asset rather than a liability to the community, the improvements required by this article shall be installed prior to the approval of the final plat. 
(1)  Monuments. All lot corners shall be marked with an iron pipe at least 24 inches long and driven to within four inches above the finished grade or flush as conditions may require. 
(2)  Natural gas. When gas lines are located in a street right-of-way, where possible the lines shall be located outside the portion of the street to be surfaced to prevent having to cut into the paved surface to serve abutting properties. 
(3)  Water supply. Water mains, valves and fire hydrants shall be installed according to plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. When required, a connection shall be stubbed out to the property line or easement line to serve all abutting lots at the time of installation of water mains. All water mains shall be installed in private easements dedicated exclusively to the city; or if water mains are installed in street rights-of-way, easements shall be dedicated prior to filing of the subdivision final plat. 
(4)  Sanitary sewers. Sanitary sewers shall be installed according to the plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. When required, a connection shall be stubbed out to the property line or easement line to serve all abutting lots at the time of installation of sewer mains. All sanitary sewer mains shall be installed in private easements dedicated exclusively to the city; or if sanitary sewer mains are installed in street rights-of-way, easements shall be dedicated prior to filing of the subdivision final plat. The developer shall obtain the appropriate permit to construct from the state department of health and environmental control on the sewer system. 
(5)  Community sewage disposal systems. Prior to the construction of any community sewage disposal system such as an oxidation pond or other facility, the location, size, plans and specifications of such a facility shall be approved by the city engineer. No wastewater treatment facility will be approved unless it is in accordance with the approved sewer plan for the area. All wastewater treatment systems must receive a permit to construct from the state department of health and environmental control. 
(6)  Curbs and gutters. Concrete curbs and gutters shall be installed in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. 
(7)  Street grading and surfacing. Street grading, base preparation and surfacing shall be carried out by the subdivider according to plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. 
(8)  Storm drainage. An adequate drainage system based on acceptable stormwater management principles, including necessary open swales and waterways, pipes, culverts, storm sewers, intersectional drains, drop inlets, bridges and other necessary appurtenances, shall be installed by the subdivider according to plans in accordance with the city storm drainage ordinance (Chapter 21, article II) and approved by the city engineer. 
(9)  Street name signs. Street name signs shall be installed at all intersections within a subdivision. The location and design of such signs shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(10)  Street trees. The planting of street trees is not required. However, if the subdivider chooses to plant trees along the street to enhance the appearance of a subdivision, the trees shall not be planted on any street right-of-way of less than 60 feet unless it can be conclusively shown that there will be no future conflict with vehicles or with utility lines either above or below the ground surface. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4041) 
Sec. 17-532. - Surety in lieu of completion of improvements. 
    After preliminary plat approval has been given, in lieu of the completion of the physical development and installation of the required improvements prior to the final approval of a plat, the city may accept a bond, in an amount and with surety and conditions satisfactory to it, providing for and securing to the city the actual construction and installation of those improvements and utilities within a period specified by the city engineer and/or city attorney and expressed in the bond. All easements and rights-of-way shall be shown on final plats and descriptions recorded prior to filing of the final plat of a subdivision under surety bond. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4042) 
Secs. 17-533-17-550. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CLUSTER HOUSING 

Sec. 17-551. - Generally. 
    The intent of residential cluster housing is to provide savings in infrastructure installation, land resources and energy use through the concentration of dwellings, construction and physical impact to specific areas of a tract. Cluster housing permits variation in lot size, shape and orientation without an increase in overall density of population or development. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4051) 
Sec. 17-552. - Procedure for plat approval. 
    As a condition of approval for cluster housing developments, all applicants shall submit plans for review by the planning commission according to the requirements of sections 17-491 and 17-492. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4051(1)) 
Sec. 17-553. - Plat requirements. 
(a)  All applicants requesting plat approval for cluster housing developments shall prepare sketch plans, preliminary plats and final plats in accordance with section 17-492 and section 17-301 pertaining to cluster housing development. 
(b)  In addition to the information required in section 17-492, all applicants for cluster housing developments shall submit the following documents showing the information indicated: 
(1)  Sketch plan. 
a.  Location and type of all proposed common buildings or other amenities. 
b.  Designation of all proposed common open space and percent. 
c.  Location and design of required parking. 
(2)  Preliminary plat (construction drawings). 
a.  Location and scaled dimensions of all proposed buildings or structures. 
b.  Designation of all proposed common open space and percent. 
c.  Typical landscaping plans. 
d.  A copy of the legal documentation for land in common ownership or restricted for common use, and the identification of areas in private ownership, common ownership, and public ownership. 
e.  The planning commission may require additional information if there is a need. 
(3)  Final plat. 
a.  Designation of all common open space and percent. 
b.  The legal documentation approved by the city attorney for land in common ownership or restricted for common use and the identification of land in common ownership, which shall be recorded along with the final plat in the office of the register of mesne conveyances. 
c.  Where phasing is proposed, each phase must independently, or when combined with previously recorded phases, meet the minimum requirements of the cluster housing regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 6-4051(2)) 
Sec. 17-554. - Design standards. 
    The following requirements are applicable to cluster housing developments: 
(1)  Street access. Any dwelling units on lots established within a cluster housing development shall be provided with access by a street which meets the requirements of this article. The minimum pavement width for such streets shall meet the requirements of section 17-512, plus sufficient public easements to accommodate utilities and storm drainage as determined by the city engineer. These pavement widths are exclusive of required parking space. All streets must be constructed to standards approved by the city engineer. 
(2)  Screening. The planning commission may require additional screening above that required by the zoning ordinance (article III of this chapter). 
(3)  Common open space. 
a.  For purposes of this section, open space is defined as that land area devoted to common use accessible by all the homeowners, exclusive of parking areas, streets and street rights-of-way, which is designed to meet the primary objective of supplying open space or recreational needs. Minimum common open space is as follows:
